title: Jock Palfreeman: Australia seems to backflip on support of his release from Bulgarian prison
text:
The Australian government has been accused of betraying an Australian man imprisoned in Bulgaria on charges of killing a student.

Jock Palfreeman was sentenced to 20 years behind bars for stabbing a university student to death in a brawl in 2007.

He has always maintained his innocence and was freed on parole last month.

But an appeal was lodged to revoke his freedom shortly after and Palfreeman was ordered to a holding facility while his case was considered - which could take up to eight weeks.

Scroll down for video

Former Sydney private school boy Jock Palfreeman, 32, has been imprisoned in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia since December 2007

At the time, Australian foreign affairs minister Marise Payne expressed her concern that the 32-year-old was being detained based on 'non-legal considerations'.

'It is our view that he should be released and we should be able to make arrangements for that to happen,' she said at the time.

In an apparent backflip on that stance, Australia's top diplomat in Athens, Jon Philip, has reportedly told Bulgarian officials Australia supports their process.

Since his incarceration, Mr Palfreeman has become an activist and gained the support of high profile lawyers

Bulgarian Justice Minister Danail Kirilov released a statement reportedly from Mr Philip which read: 'Australia is aware that currently everything is proceeding according to Bulgarian law and there are no deviations in the judiciary process.'

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is yet to clarify whether the statement is accurate.

In response to the alleged reversal, Palfreeman told the ABC he felt betrayed by the Australian government.

'If this is true, this is a major betrayal by Australia, and it would have been better if they would never have been involved in the first place,' he said.

'If it's not true then Bulgarian authorities have basically forced Australia to have to confront this email that the Minister of Justice has sent around, to either confirm or deny it.'

Palfreeman has now spent 19 days in a detention facility after the Sofia Court of Appeal granted him parole.

Palfreeman was charged over the murder of law student Andrei Monov, 20, (left) in a melee on the streets while travelling on an 'extended gap year'

The decision was appealed by Bulgarian prosecutor general Sotir Tsatsarov, but could take up to eight weeks to be finalised.

Palfreeman's lawyer, Kalin Angelov, called the prosecutor's appeal 'absurd.'

He says he advised Australian authorities to speed up the passport and put Palfreeman on a plane home.

Jock Palfreeman was 19 and travelling about eastern Europe on an 'extended gap year' in 2007 when he was arrested over the death of law student Andrei Monov, 20.

Palfreeman, a former student of Sydney's elite The King's School, claimed he had stepped in to try an help a gypsy, who was being hounded by drunk youths.

But prosecutors alleged he had set upon Monov on the streets of the capital, Sofia, without provocation, and killed him in cold blood.

authors: Brittany Chain For Daily Mail Australia
